title: Monday, 12th November 2018

annotations.prefLabel: Washington Post Co (Old name of Graham Holdings Co)

bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Gah.

Blank canvas Hi
BE11:04am

Also, good morning. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's whatever.

Tsetse Gah morning
VV75 morning
VV75 happy monday
BE11:05am

Here for another hour of "Brexit noise makes the pound go up and down sort of".

Grouchmonkey Morning
Soundbuy Morning
11:06 am
BE11:06am

Though I'm beginning to lose my faith in financial markets being an accurate barometer of political velocity. Want to know why? Here's why.

British American Tobacco PLC (BATS:LSE): Last: 3,035, down 280 (-8.45%), High: 3,070, Low: 2,950, Volume: 3.24m
PBateman Morning all

Okay, so this is ridic.

PBateman ah BATS, just what I came for
11:07 am
BE11:07am

What happened was that, on Friday, the Washington Post did a preview story on the FDA's ecig policy update due later this week.

BE11:07am

Its report led off with the line that most flavour pods would be banned.

BE11:08am

And the response was ..... hooray! Because banning mango and tutti fruiti vapes has the biggest effect on Juul ........

PBateman followed by..
11:09 am
BE11:09am

...... the independent US vape thing that's taken a lion's share of the market and entirely coincidentally has adverts that seem to appeal to quite a young demographic.

Grouchmonkey Babcock? That's entertaining.
BE11:09am

Clip Juul's wings and that's good for big tobacco. So goes the theory. Buy big tobacco. That was Friday.

BE11:10am

Course, no one read beyond the first four pars of the Washington Post article, to the bit that it said the FDA "is [also] expected to propose banning menthol in regular cigarettes".

11:11 am
BE11:11am

So when the WSJ wrote an identical story with the facts in a slightly different order on Friday night, the result is .... what, 9% off BAT.

PBateman USA menthol 25pc of BATS profit iirc
BE11:12am

Efficient markets. So long as your definition of efficiency means only reading the first four paragraphs of news reports.

cheeckychappy Morning Brycey!
BE11:12am

It's also worth noting that Gottlieb's been saying since forever that he wants a menthol ban.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

"Flavors are a problem. They entice kids to initiate on cigarettes. Menthol may make it easier to hook young smokers. We have the legal authority and the public health obligation to address these risks.”

PBateman Jefferies saying it won't happen apparently, not seen the note mind
Pharma Because people who can't get menthol fags are going to stop smoking, rather than switch to something else? That's a convincing argument.
BE11:13am

NONE OF THIS IS NEWS!

cheeckychappy Perhaps it's all these paywalls that are creating inefficient markets/information arbitrage...discuss?
BE11:13am

Okay, so here are the figures.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @BE Perhaps you can get the guys over on FastFT to be a little on the mark. The BATS story has been all over the markets this morning not on FastFT. I had to go to BBC news live.
11:13 am
BE11:13am

(@Pbateman: patience, ffs.)

BE11:13am

This is PiperJaffray.

BE11:14am

While the near-term issue is primarily headline risk, BAT has the greatest menthol exposure, as menthol cigarettes are 55-60% of US volumes and drive 25-27% of global profit. We estimate menthol cigarettes are about 18-20% of its cigarette volumes and about 15-17% of profits. For Imperial, we estimate menthol to be about 25% of its US volumes, or 6-8% of its global profit. While we are not yet aware of any official news from the FDA, it looks as though news may come as soon as this week. Legal challenges can only be made to final rules, and the path to a final rule can be lengthy, so we estimate 8 or more years before any potential implementation.

Pharma @cheecky, perhaps it's the FDA leaking market-moving information to the papers, rather than releasing it to the public.
11:14 am
BE11:14am

EIGHT YEARS!

PBateman haha
BE11:14am

The FDA has issued an advanced notice of proposed rulemaking (ANPR) for flavors in cigarettes (such as menthol) which it has used to gather information and begin a public dialogue. The steps afterwards leading up to any potential final rules are likely to take 8, 10 or more years (and a final rule is still not a given). The time it takes to compile necessary scientific evidence for a proposed rule (typically several years), prove a rule would have limited unintended consequences (i.e. illicit trade and implement a rule make for a lengthy timeline, even before any legal challenges are included (challenges can only be made to final rules). There is a mandatory 1-year delay to implement a rule . The process can be slower still with potential additional analyses (e.g. economic impact).

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian It's all corrupt. The US, FDA, lobbying etc.. etc.. IMO of course. You make your own mind up!
BE11:15am

And Jefferies goes for five years plus.

Grouchmonkey 8 YEARS of legal challenges? Well, that's something to look forward to .
PBateman watching my Caribbean island tobacco-funded retirement dreams disintegrate in front of my eyes
PBateman Buying Spire instead
11:16 am
BE11:16am

In our note on Friday we went into the history of menthol and how the FDA has not been able to ban menthol to date due to lack of evidence, and the ability to prove a health benefit to the population as a whole. While we noted this may have changed with the availability of RRP [i.e. if they can show menthol users will switch over to RRP then there is a health benefit], gathering this evidence would take time [and still may never be conclusive enough]. The WSJ article pretty much confirmed this [and we would say was less concerning than the Post article which raised the risk of a rule being proposed this week] when it said "it could take a year or more for a rule banning menthol to be finalised, and then for another year for it to be enforceable in the marketplace". This also ignores any legal challenges. In reality, this would be a c.5 year process at least, in our view.

BE11:16am

The second thing we would flag when assessing a menthol ban is the threat is not as great as it was previously. The only way they can support a ban now is if they can show users switch over to RRP (and therefore a health benefit). In such a case, is it really a significant negative? The risk before under a menthol ban would be users quit vs switching into RRP. As long as you get comfort big tobacco is taking a fair share of those switching (we know questions over Juul taking some of these volumes at the moment), then the impact is likely to be less than many will fear.

BE11:18am

So the most you can say here, really, is "ooh, the FDA sure don't like smoking".

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Which, I mean, fair enough. But again, incremental news at best.

BE11:18am

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:18am

We do not know if the FDA will announce plans to ban menthol, but between the FDA's Comprehensive Tobacco Regulatory Plan that aims to reduce nicotine in cigarettes to non-addictive levels and the recent heightened scrutiny on e-cigs, the FDA is reasserting its authority over the industry. A renewed focus on menthol could raise questions/provide clarity about the FDA's plans/timing of reducing nicotine levels in cigarettes. While FDA tobacco oversight has done little to impact the industry's business model to date, we expect increasing uncertainty to remain an overhang and cap multiples in the near-to-medium term.

BE11:25am

Peel Hunt runs through the list of questions on the proposed Wagamama deal.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

• What assumption changes drove the deal to being downgraded to dilutive in the first year?
• Can you adjust the 13.2x EBITDA multiple to reflect 5-10% of Wagamama’s leases ending over the next five years? How profitable are these sites?
• Why did Wagamama’s rent per site rise by 25% over the last two years?
• How do you achieve £22m of synergies with Wagamama being run autonomously?
• How do you grow Wagamama’s LFL sales long term if the sites are now trading at full capacity at peak times?
• Where do you anticipate the combined labour ratio moving to from the current level of 36% of sales?

BE11:26am

• - How dependent are LFL sales on delivery and how profitable is delivery?
• Does management believe it can simultaneously integrate Wagamama, integrate pub acquisitions, invest in new digital channels, expand Wagamama in the US and franchises internationally, and not be distracted in the attempt to turn around Frankie & Benny’s, Coast to Coast and Chiquito?

BE11:27am

Peel also highlights that the directors pushing the deal only own 0.07% of the company.

chad_john "How do you grow Wagamama’s LFL sales long term if the sites are now trading at full capacity at peak times?" - quite. There's only so much mochi you can upsell.
11:27 am
BE11:27am

While rather more of the shareholder list is income and value

Tom Dalgleish I love those 1 year profit accretive projections
BE11:28am

Liberum:

BE11:28am

We estimate the acquisition of Wagamama is marginally dilutive in the first full-year (FY19E) by -2.3% but from FY20E accretive by more than 13%. At a strike price of 108.5p, the scale of the dilution to the existing TRG shareholders is quite alarming putting existing shareholders in a difficult position. Does TRG need this deal, probably not, and we baulked at the price when originally announced. We also do not feel a RoIC exceeding WACC by Year 3 as attractive enough. On current trading we are encouraged that TRG remains on track noting the comment that "TRG expects Adj PBT to be not less than £50m for FY18E” vs. Liberum forecast of £51.1m and that Wagamama has seen LFLs +12.2% for the 11-weeks to 4 November. The shares are likely to come under pressure today and we keep our TP U/R but remain of the view that this deal is a very steep price.

Given the negativity around the shares we believe that this will have the desired effect of calming nerves and expect a positive reaction today. In other news, the additional £1bn p.a. for the MoD in the budget in October was marginally helpful. The NAO reported on 1st November that the MoD Equipment Plan for 2018 to 2028 ‘remains unaffordable’ and the gap could be £14.8bn ‘although we consider this could still be optimistic’. News last week that Toshiba has shut its NuGen plant in Moorside is a small long term negative. We are more optimistic about the future of Wylfa nuclear power station, where Atkins won a civil design contract last month. The CY 2019 P/E of 6.8x is simply too low, which is why we felt confident choosing it as a key pick in our sector piece last week

The US account for c45% of group profits (c91% of N America). We estimate the US tailbrands account for c10% of Diageo US spirits declining at c4%-5% p.a. Depending on timing of the deal (estimated early FY19), the loss of the brands will improve US spirits growth by 40bp. We have previously written about two key drivers of growth acceleration from more active management of the portfolio with repositioning (e.g., Casamigos transaction) and selling the tail, which could be worth up to c50bp to growth.

From our conversations with Diageo, we understand that the brands being sold have sales of c.$180m (£140m). We estimate brand contribution of c.$94m (£75m). The disposal will reduce NA EBIT margins by -65bps. However, given that tail portfolio sales were declining at c.-11% per annum, their removal should enhance Diageo’s US spirits & wine OSG by c.+40bps, North America divisional OSG c.+30bps and group OSG by c.+10bps.

Looking forward we expect management to turn their attention to generating more value via portfolio change from beer. Guinness is arguably the original ‘craft’ beer and its Coca-Cola-like characteristics mean Diageo could/should consider an asset-light roll-out strategy in partnership with other global brewer. If this fails, a £11.4bn sale and exit from beer is possible.
